template.name: AWS_Account Assessment for AWS Organizations
template.desc: Account Assessment for AWS Organizations allows you to centrally manage and evaluate all AWS accounts within your AWS Organizations, helping you to better understand and navigate the dependencies of AWS Organizations. The process to manually evaluate AWS Organizations dependencies can be time consuming—potentially involving reviews of tens or even hundreds of AWS resources of individual accounts. Now, you can run three types of scans to find delegated administrator accounts, identity-based and resource-based policies, and AWS services that have trusted access enabled for your AWS Organizations—all from a simple UI.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive auditing and monitoring of all API calls and actions made through AWS API Gateway, configure AWS CloudTrail to record these activities. This setup is critical for maintaining a transparent and secure environment. Follow these steps:

  1. Enable AWS CloudTrail: Make sure AWS CloudTrail is enabled in your AWS account. CloudTrail records all API calls made to AWS services, including API Gateway, and stores the log files in an S3 bucket.
    AWS CloudTrail Documentation
  2. Create a Trail: Create a trail to capture all API Gateway calls. A trail configuration allows you to capture management and data events for API Gateway resources.
    Creating a CloudTrail Trail
  3. Configure Logging for API Gateway: Ensure that API Gateway logging is enabled. You can configure it in the API Gateway console under the logging settings for each API stage.
    Setting up CloudWatch API Logging for API Gateway
  4. Verify Logging and Monitoring: Consistently monitor the logs produced in CloudTrail and CloudWatch. This proactive measure will help in early detection of any unauthorized or suspicious activities.
    AWS Security Hub Recommended Standards

By following these steps, you will enhance the visibility and security of your AWS API Gateway environment, ensuring that all activities are recorded and monitored effectively.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure compliance and detect unauthorized changes in your AWS API Gateway resources, use AWS Config to continuously monitor and evaluate their configurations. AWS Config provides a detailed view of the AWS resource configurations, their relationships, and changes over time.

Here’s a step-by-step guide for cloud engineers to implement this control:

  1. Enable AWS Config in your AWS account. Follow the documentation to set up AWS Config by defining an IAM role with the necessary permissions, specifying an S3 bucket to store configuration snapshots, and selecting the AWS resources you want to monitor.
  2. Create a Config Rule to evaluate the configuration of your API Gateway resources. AWS Config provides a set of managed rules, or you can create custom rules using AWS Lambda. For API Gateway, you might use the AWS-managed rule called "api-gateway-gateway-response-check", which checks for best practices and compliance.
  3. Use the AWS Config console or CLI to associate the rules with the API Gateway resources. Define the compliance criteria that the rule will evaluate, such as specific security configurations or limits.
  4. Set up notifications for non-compliance using Amazon SNS. This can help in alerting teams instantaneously if there are unauthorized changes or misconfigurations detected.
  5. Regularly review the compliance status and history of changes in the AWS Config dashboard to maintain best practices and ensure security measures are consistently applied.

Refer to the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices for more details on maintaining a secure configuration for your API Gateway resources.

countermeasure.name: Implement Amazon CloudWatch alarms
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure robust security monitoring of your API Gateway, it's critical to leverage Amazon CloudWatch metrics and alarms. This proactive measure will aid in the prompt detection and response to any anomalies or potential security issues.

Begin by accessing the Amazon CloudWatch console within AWS Management Console. Navigate to the "Metrics" section to ensure you are monitoring the relevant metrics for API Gateway. Key metrics to focus on include:

  • 4XXError: Counts the number of client-side errors (useful for detecting potential abuse).
  • 5XXError: Counts the number of server-side errors (indicates the health of the backend or integration).
  • Count: Number of API requests received (to identify unusual spikes in traffic).
  • Latency: Measures the time taken from the API Gateway receiving a request until it responds (to detect performance degradation).

After identifying these metrics, set up CloudWatch Alarms to notify your security team when any of the thresholds are breached. To do this:

  1. In the CloudWatch console, go to "Alarms" and click on "Create Alarm".
  2. Select the API Gateway metric you want to monitor, such as 4XXError or 5XXError.
  3. Define the appropriate thresholds based on your security policy. For instance, configure an alarm to trigger if the 5XXError exceeds a specific number within a predetermined timeframe.
  4. Set up notification actions, such as sending an alert to an AWS SNS topic, which will forward the notification to the relevant personnel via email or SMS.
  5. Optionally, automate responses using AWS Lambda functions to handle detected anomalies, like throttling suspicious IPs or alerting a security operations center (SOC).

Additionally, ensure compliance with security best practices by reviewing the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation regularly.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ensure that resources within AWS API Gateway are only accessible by authorized entities, it is pivotal to utilize IAM policies that adhere to the principle of least privilege. This approach minimizes the risk of unauthorized access and potential security breaches. Implementing this countermeasure involves creating precise and restrictive IAM policies that grant the minimum necessary permissions required for users or roles to perform their functions.

Follow these steps to implement IAM policies based on the principle of least privilege:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the exact permissions needed by each user, role, or service account to interact with AWS API Gateway. Avoid granting broad permissions that are not necessary.
  2. Create Custom IAM Policies: Write custom IAM policies that define granular permissions. Use specific actions (e.g., `apigateway:GET`, `apigateway:POST`) and restrict access to the necessary resources (e.g., specific API IDs or stages).
  3. Apply the Policies: Attach the custom IAM policies to the relevant IAM users, groups, or roles. Ensure that the policies are evaluated and tested to confirm they provide the intended access without excess permissions.
  4. Enable Policy Versioning and Logging: Maintain policy versioning to keep track of changes and use AWS CloudTrail for monitoring and logging API Gateway access activity, which helps in auditing and compliance.
  5. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review the permissions and update IAM policies as needed to adapt to any changes in requirements or security posture.

For more detailed information and best practices on securing your API Gateway using IAM policies, refer to the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation.

countermeasure.name: Implement logging
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure visibility and traceability of all activities occurring in your AWS API Gateway, it is essential to implement monitoring and logging mechanisms using Amazon CloudWatch Logs or Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. This practice aligns with the security guidelines as specified in the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable API Gateway Execution Logging: Access the API Gateway in the AWS Management Console and navigate to the stage settings. Under the Logs/Tracing tab, enable Access Logging and specify the CloudWatch Logs group. Follow the detailed instructions in the API Gateway Logging Setup Guide.
  2. Set up CloudWatch Logs: If using CloudWatch Logs, ensure that the necessary IAM roles and permissions are in place to allow API Gateway to write logs. Configure log retention policies according to your organizational compliance requirements.
  3. Implement Kinesis Data Firehose: If opting for Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose, create a delivery stream to capture the logs and optionally transform and load them into destination services such as Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift, or Amazon Elasticsearch Service. For integration, refer to Creating an Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose Delivery Stream.
  4. Review and Monitor Logs: Regularly review the logs to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts. Set up CloudWatch Alarms to alert your security team of any suspicious activities.
By adhering to these guidelines and leveraging CloudWatch Logs or Kinesis Data Firehose, you can enhance the security posture of your API Gateway by maintaining comprehensive visibility and traceability of API operations.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Security Hub
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Security Hub provides a comprehensive view of security alerts and compliance status across AWS accounts for API Gateway implementations. By integrating AWS Security Hub with your AWS API Gateway, you can effectively manage and monitor security risks and ensure adherence to best practices. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:
  1. Enable AWS Security Hub: Start by enabling AWS Security Hub in the AWS Management Console. Navigate to the Security Hub dashboard and select "Get Started." Ensure it's activated in the appropriate AWS region where your API Gateway resources are hosted.

    Reference: Setting Up AWS Security Hub

  2. Configure Findings and Insights: AWS Security Hub aggregates findings from various AWS services. Ensure that findings from AWS API Gateway are included. Inspect and prioritize these findings to understand the security and compliance status.

    Reference: Understanding Findings

  3. Enable Security Standards: Activate relevant security standards like the AWS Foundational Security Best Practices standard to receive automated checks for common security configurations and vulnerabilities in your API Gateway setup.

    Reference: AWS Foundational Security Best Practices

  4. Regularly Review and Act: Regularly review the insights and findings provided by Security Hub. Implement recommended actions, such as applying least privilege principles, enabling logging and monitoring, and ensuring proper API Gateway configuration as advised in the AWS API Gateway security best practices.

    Reference: API Gateway Security Best Practices

By systematically implementing these steps, you can ensure that your AWS API Gateway environments are securely managed and compliant with established security best practices.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured IAM policies can create vulnerabilities by allowing unauthorized users to access and manipulate API Gateway resources, leading to security breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders who exploit weak or overly permissive IAM policies to gain access to API Gateway resources.
Impacts
Unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exposure of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies an IAM policy that grants overly broad permissions and uses it to access and modify API Gateway settings, potentially disrupting services or exfiltrating data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Non-compliance with security best practices
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failing to continuously monitor and adhere to security best practices can expose the system to vulnerabilities and lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include cyber attackers, malicious insiders, and even accidental misconfigurations. Attack vectors can be as diverse as exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities, pivoting through misconfigured services, and taking advantage of outdated security frameworks.
Impacts
The impacts may include data breaches, financial losses, legal penalties, damage to reputation, and disruption of business operations. Regulatory non-compliance can result in fines and restrictions on business activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A cyber attacker identifies unpatched vulnerabilities in the API Gateway and exploits them to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. 2. Due to lack of continuous monitoring, an internal user accidentally misconfigures security settings, exposing critical resources to the internet. 3. Failure to adhere to encryption best practices leads to data being transmitted in plaintext, which is intercepted by an attacker.

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Delayed threat detection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without continuous monitoring and alerting, security threats may go undetected for extended periods, increasing the likelihood of significant damage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors can exploit vulnerabilities in your AWS infrastructure that are not promptly identified due to inadequate monitoring and alerting systems. This includes issues like unpatched software, misconfigurations, and unauthorized access attempts.
Impacts
Delayed detection can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, data loss, and potentially significant downtime. There can also be financial repercussions, reputational damage, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to your AWS API Gateway due to a misconfiguration. Without monitoring, this unauthorized activity goes unnoticed, allowing the attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data over a prolonged period.
2. A vulnerability in an API is exploited, but because continuous monitoring is not in place, the breach is discovered only after considerable damage has been done.
3. An insider modifies configurations maliciously, leading to data leaks or system downtimes that are only detected after client complaints.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit trails
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without audit trails, it is challenging to track changes and access patterns to API Gateway resources, increasing the risk of undetected security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers, internal malicious users, or even compromised legitimate users. Attack vectors can include unauthorized access, modification of API configurations, and attempts to exploit vulnerabilities in the API.
Impacts
The lack of audit trails can lead to severe impacts including data breaches, unauthorized access, unnoticed manipulation of sensitive information, and difficulties in incident response and forensic investigation.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An external attacker gains access to API Gateway and modifies API configurations to exfiltrate sensitive data without detection. 2. An internal employee with malicious intent changes configurations and accesses sensitive customer data, remaining undetected due to the lack of audit trails. 3. A legitimate user’s account is compromised and used to exploit an API vulnerability, causing data leakage and operational disruptions without raising any alarms.

threat.name: Unmonitored changes and activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper logging, unauthorized changes and activities can go unnoticed, leading to potential vulnerabilities and compliance issues.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal employees or external attackers making unauthorized changes, malicious activities occurring within the AWS environment.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, non-compliance with industry regulations, potential financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal employee alters API configurations without authorization, leading to data exposure. An attacker exploits an API vulnerability, and the lack of logging prevents early detection and response. Audits reveal insufficient logging, resulting in compliance fines.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Configuration drift
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unmonitored configuration changes can lead to configuration drift, making the environment non-compliant with security policies and prone to vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel, accidental misconfigurations, or insider threats making untracked changes to the configuration settings.
Impacts
Breach of security policies, increased vulnerability to attacks, potential data breaches, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
An insider makes a change to the API Gateway configuration that disables logging, making it difficult to detect malicious activities. Unknown to the security team, an attacker exploits the misconfigured resource, leading to a data breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Configure origin access control to restrict CloudFront distribution access
countermeasure.desc: To enhance the security of your AWS CloudFront distributions, implement Origin Access Control (OAC) to restrict access to your origin servers. By configuring OAC, you ensure that only CloudFront has the necessary permissions to fetch content from the origin, preventing unauthorized access and modifications. This control involves creating an OAC, attaching it to your CloudFront distribution, and configuring your origin server (e.g., S3 bucket, custom origin) to only accept requests signed with the OAC signature. Regularly review and update OAC settings to align with any changes in your security posture or application architecture. Refer to AWS CloudFront Security Best Practices for detailed configuration steps and requirements.

reference.name: Restrict access to an AWS origin

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all data transmission and redirect HTTP to HTTPS
countermeasure.desc: To secure data transmitted between CloudFront and both viewers and origin servers, ensure that all communication is encrypted using HTTPS. Configure your CloudFront distribution to automatically redirect all incoming HTTP requests to HTTPS, preventing unencrypted data transmission. This can be achieved by setting up a custom error response for HTTP requests or by enforcing HTTPS in the CloudFront behavior settings. By enforcing HTTPS and redirecting HTTP traffic, you protect sensitive information from being intercepted, ensuring secure communication across your entire CloudFront distribution.

reference.name: Require HTTPS for communication between viewers and CloudFront

countermeasure.name: Implement signed URLs and signed cookies to restrict content access
countermeasure.desc: To ensure that only authorized users can access specific resources served by your AWS CloudFront distribution, use signed URLs and signed cookies. Signed URLs are ideal for granting temporary access to individual files, while signed cookies allow access to multiple restricted files. Configure these mechanisms to include expiration dates and IP whitelisting to further control access. Generate and manage the cryptographic keys securely to prevent unauthorized use. By implementing signed URLs and signed cookies, you can effectively restrict content access, protecting your resources from unauthorized distribution or consumption.

reference.name: Serve private content with signed URLs and signed cookies

countermeasure.name: Integrate AWS WAF with CloudFront to mitigate web exploits
countermeasure.desc: To protect your AWS CloudFront distribution from common web exploits such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting (XSS), integrate AWS Web Application Firewall (WAF) with CloudFront. AWS WAF allows you to create custom rules that filter and monitor HTTP and HTTPS requests based on defined conditions. Implement predefined managed rule groups for comprehensive protection against known vulnerabilities, and configure custom rules tailored to your application’s specific security requirements. Regularly review and update your WAF rules to adapt to evolving threats, ensuring that your CloudFront distribution remains secure against web-based attacks.

countermeasure.name: Utilize version control for CloudFront configuration management
countermeasure.desc: Implement version control to manage and track changes to your AWS CloudFront distribution configurations. This practice allows you to maintain a history of configuration changes, making it easier to identify, audit, and revert any unintended or harmful modifications. Use tools such as AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or Git to version your configuration files, enabling consistent and repeatable deployments. In case of a misconfiguration or security issue, version control provides a straightforward path to roll back to a previous stable state, ensuring the reliability and security of your CloudFront distribution.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to CloudFront distribution
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to a CloudFront distribution occurs when an attacker gains access to the CloudFront distribution settings or content without proper authorization. This can lead to the manipulation of distribution settings, theft of sensitive data, or disruption of services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Compromised AWS credentials, insufficient access controls, exposed API keys.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized users may access or steal sensitive content.
  • Integrity: Attackers could modify distribution settings or content, leading to the distribution of malicious or incorrect information.
  • Availability: Attackers may disrupt services by altering or disabling the distribution.
  • Reputation: Loss of customer trust and potential legal consequences from data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker uses compromised AWS credentials to access and alter CloudFront settings, redirecting users to malicious content.
  2. Scenario 2: Insufficient access controls allow a former employee to log in and disrupt the CloudFront distribution, causing service outages.
  3. Scenario 3: An exposed API key is exploited to access CloudFront configurations, resulting in unauthorized changes to content delivery.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Data leakage through unencrypted data in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data leakage occurs when sensitive information is transmitted over the network without encryption. In AWS CloudFront, this happens when data moves between edge locations, clients, or origin servers using insecure protocols like HTTP, making it vulnerable to interception.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, state-sponsored actors, competitors.
  • Attack Vectors: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, compromised network infrastructure.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data like login credentials and personal information.
  • Integrity: Potential alteration of data in transit.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand trust and legal repercussions.
  • Financial Loss: Regulatory fines, litigation costs, and loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts unencrypted HTTP traffic on public Wi-Fi to steal user credentials.
  2. Scenario 2: Unencrypted software updates are intercepted and maliciously altered.
  3. Scenario 3: A state-sponsored actor intercepts unencrypted corporate data, leading to espionage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

threat.name: Misconfigured CloudFront distributions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description Misconfigured CloudFront distributions can lead to serious security vulnerabilities, such as unauthorized access, data exposure, or service disruptions. These misconfigurations may include improper access settings, insecure SSL/TLS configurations, or incorrect origin server permissions, making the distribution susceptible to attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, careless administrators.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of public S3 buckets, unauthorized access to CloudFront distributions, insecure SSL/TLS settings.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized users.
  • Integrity: Potential modification of data served by CloudFront.
  • Availability: Disruptions in service or unintended public access to private content.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand image due to security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An S3 bucket linked to CloudFront is left publicly accessible, allowing attackers to download sensitive files.
  2. Scenario 2: A misconfigured SSL/TLS setting allows attackers to perform a MitM attack, intercepting data between the client and CloudFront.
  3. Scenario 3: Origin server permissions are too broad, allowing unauthorized users to alter content served by CloudFront.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Content tampering
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Content tampering occurs when an attacker alters the content delivered through a CloudFront distribution. This can involve modifying or injecting malicious code, defacing web pages, or changing the data served to end-users. Such tampering can lead to a variety of harmful outcomes, including the distribution of malware, misinformation, or unauthorized data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in origin servers, unauthorized access to CloudFront configurations, man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Impacts

  • Integrity: Altered content can mislead users, distribute malware, or damage trust.
  • Reputation: Users may lose trust in the organization due to the distribution of tampered or harmful content.
  • Legal and Compliance: Organizations may face legal action or fines if tampered content results in harm to users or violates regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker gains unauthorized access to the origin server and modifies the web application files, causing users to download malware.
  2. Scenario 2: A hacker intercepts and alters data being transmitted from the origin to CloudFront, leading to the delivery of defaced or misleading content.
  3. Scenario 3: A malicious insider modifies content on an origin server that is distributed via CloudFront, resulting in the display of unauthorized or offensive material.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1492 - Stored Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-613
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-613: Insufficient Session Expiration According to WASC, "Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization."

countermeasure.name: Apply fine-grained identity policies
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ensure precise control over user access to resources, implement fine-grained identity policies using AWS Cognito. This approach involves creating specific IAM policies that tightly control what authenticated and unauthenticated users can access.

Begin by defining user roles and associating them with appropriate IAM policies. For instance, authenticated users might have policies granting them access to user-specific resources, whereas unauthenticated users might have restricted access.

Here's a step-by-step guide for a cloud engineer:

  1. Create an IAM Role for Authenticated Users
    • Navigate to the IAM console and create a new role for authenticated users.
    • Attach a policy to this role that grants permissions to access only specific resources. Use JSON policy documents for greater precision. Refer to the Cognito IAM roles documentation for example policies.
  2. Create an IAM Role for Unauthenticated Users
    • Similarly, create another role for unauthenticated users, ensuring the policy attached to this role is more restrictive.
  3. Associate Roles with Cognito Identity Pool
    • Navigate to the Cognito console and choose your identity pool.
    • Edit the identity pool settings to assign the roles created above to authenticated and unauthenticated users respectively.
  4. Test the Policies
    • Validate that authenticated users have the correct level of access and that unauthenticated users are appropriately restricted.

For more detailed information, refer to the AWS Cognito security guidelines and specific references on IAM roles.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of user accounts in AWS Cognito, it is highly recommended to enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). By integrating MFA, an additional layer of protection is provided, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. Follow the guidelines below to implement MFA for your Cognito user pool:

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console and navigate to the Amazon Cognito service.
  2. Select the user pool for which you want to enable MFA.
  3. In the left-hand navigation pane, choose MFA and verifications.
  4. Under the Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) section, configure your desired MFA settings:
    • Set the MFA status to Optional or Required based on your security needs.
    • Select the MFA methods you wish to enable, such as SMS or TOTP (Time-based One-Time Password).
  5. Configure the SMS or TOTP settings accordingly. For SMS, ensure you have an appropriate SMS role with sufficient permissions. For TOTP, users will need to register their compatible authenticator application.
  6. Save the changes to the user pool settings.

Following these steps will significantly enhance the security posture of your user accounts by leveraging MFA. For further information on configuring MFA with AWS Cognito, refer to the official documentation: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) in Amazon Cognito.

Additional detailed security considerations can be explored in the AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to sensitive user attributes
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing access control for sensitive user attributes in AWS Cognito is essential to enhance security and ensure that such attributes are only accessible by authorized users or services. Follow these guidelines to appropriately restrict access:

Step-by-Step Implementation:

  1. Define Sensitive User Attributes: Identify and label sensitive user attributes in your user pool. These could include PII (Personally Identifiable Information) such as email addresses, phone numbers, or any custom attributes that hold sensitive information.
  2. Configure User Pool Policies: Utilize Amazon Cognito’s user pool settings to specify which attributes are sensitive and should have restricted access. This can be configured in the user pool attributes settings.
  3. Leverage IAM Policies: Create and enforce IAM policies for the roles and users accessing the user pool. Ensure that these policies adhere to the principle of least privilege, granting the minimum required permissions to access necessary attributes. More details on setting up secure policies can be found in the IAM policy examples.
  4. Use Amazon Cognito Contextual Data: Implement the use of contextual information (such as IP addresses, device types, etc.) to enhance security conditions under which an attribute can be accessed or modified. This approach helps mitigate unauthorized access from unexpected locations or devices.
  5. Audit and Monitor Access: Regularly audit and monitor access to sensitive user attributes using Amazon CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail. Enable logging and set up alerts for any suspicious or unauthorized access attempts. Refer to the Cognito Streams documentation for guidance on setting up logging and monitoring.
  6. Implement Encryption: Ensure that sensitive user attributes are encrypted both in transit and at rest. AWS Cognito provides built-in encryption for user data at rest, but ensure that transport layer encryption such as TLS is configured correctly for your user pool endpoints. More information can be found in the encryption documentation.

By following these steps and utilizing the features provided by AWS Cognito, cloud engineers can effectively limit access to sensitive user attributes, ensuring that only authorized users or services can access this information. For comprehensive security practices and guidelines, refer to the AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Set up proper session validity periods
countermeasure.desc:
To configure appropriate session validity periods and refresh token policies in AWS Cognito and thereby minimize the window of opportunity for session-based attacks, a cloud engineer should follow these steps:

  • Set Appropriate Session Timeout:

To mitigate potential session-based attacks, it is crucial to configure appropriate session timeout settings. AWS Cognito allows you to set the session duration through the app client settings. Navigate to the AWS Cognito console, select your user pool, and go to the "App clients" settings. Here, configure the Refresh Token Expiration and Token Expiration values to an appropriate timeframe based on your security requirements.

Refer to the following documentation for detailed instructions: AWS Cognito Token Endpoint Documentation.

  • Implement Refresh Token Rotation:

For enhanced security, implement a refresh token rotation policy. This means generating a new refresh token every time the refresh operation is performed. AWS Cognito supports refresh token rotation to further minimize the window in which a stolen token could be used. In the AWS Cognito console, under your user pool settings, enable the PreventUserExistenceErrors option, and configure the refresh token rotation as needed.

For more details, refer to the official security documentation: AWS Cognito Security Best Practices.

  • Regularly Review and Update Policies:

Frequently audit and update your session validity periods and refresh token policies to ensure they align with current security best practices and the evolving threat landscape. This proactive approach helps to continually minimize potential attack vectors.

Consult the following official resource for guidance: AWS Cognito Security Best Practices.

By carefully configuring session validity periods and refresh token policies following AWS Cognito security guidelines, you can significantly reduce the risk of session-based attacks on your applications.

countermeasure.name: Validate JWT tokens
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the proper validation of JWT tokens and confirm their authenticity and integrity, cloud engineers should implement the following countermeasures based on the official AWS Cognito documentation:

1. Verify the Signature: AWS Cognito issues JWT tokens that are signed using a key. To verify the signature, you must use the JSON Web Key Set (JWKS) provided by AWS Cognito. Retrieve the JWKS from the provided URL and use it to validate the token's signature. Reference: AWS Cognito - Verifying a JSON Web Token.

2. Check the Token Expiration: Inspect the "exp" claim in the JWT to ensure that the token has not expired. This check prevents the use of tokens past their validity period, mitigating the risk of replay attacks. Reference for security measures: AWS Cognito Security.

3. Validate the Audience (aud) Claim: The "aud" claim should match the expected audience value configured in your application. This ensures that the token was issued for your specific application and not an unintended audience. Reference: AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

4. Verify the Issuer (iss) Claim: Ensure that the "iss" claim matches the expected issuer URL for your AWS Cognito user pool. This confirms that the token was issued by your trusted user pool. Reference: Verifying a JWT - AWS Cognito.

5. Validate the Token Claims: In addition to the above claims, validate any other token claims that your application relies on for authorization, such as "sub" for user ID and custom claims included in the token. Reference: Security guidelines for AWS Cognito.

6. Regularly Update Your JWKS: AWS rotates the signing keys periodically. Ensure your implementation can handle key rotation by regularly fetching the JWKS and updating your verification mechanisms accordingly. Reference: Using and Verifying Tokens.

By following these guidelines, cloud engineers can robustly validate JWT tokens, ensuring their authenticity and integrity, and thereby significantly enhance the security posture of applications leveraging AWS Cognito.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inadequate authorization controls
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured authorization policies can allow users to gain access to resources they should not have access to, potentially leading to data manipulation or leakage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders exploiting weak or misconfigured authorization policies to gain access to sensitive data or resources illegally.
Impacts
Data breach, unauthorized data modification, loss of data integrity, and potential legal and financial repercussions for failing to protect sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers a misconfiguration in AWS Cognito authorization policies that grant excessive permissions. By exploiting this, they access confidential customer data, modify records, and exfiltrate sensitive information, leading to significant harm to the organization's reputation and financial standing.

threat.name: Data exposure due to misconfigured tokens
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper management of tokens can lead to exposure of sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised applications can intercept or misuse improperly managed tokens.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to user accounts, unauthorized actions within user contexts, and potential data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts a token transmitted over an insecure channel and uses it to gain unauthorized access to a user account. Alternatively, an insider with access to token storage leverages the token to perform unauthorized actions within the application.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Exposed user attributes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured user attribute policies can lead to exposure of sensitive personal information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors may exploit misconfigurations in user attribute policies to access, alter, or extract sensitive information stored within AWS Cognito.
Impacts
This can result in unauthorized access to PII (Personally Identifiable Information), leading to privacy violations, data breaches, and potential financial and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers that email addresses and phone numbers are set to be publicly readable in the User Pool. By leveraging this misconfiguration, they can harvest this sensitive information for phishing attacks or identity theft. Another scenario might involve an insider modifying attribute policies to expose additional sensitive attributes without proper authorization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1531 - Account Access Removal

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Compromised accounts due to poor multi-factor authentication (MFA)
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without multi-factor authentication (MFA), accounts become susceptible to unauthorized access if credentials are phished or otherwise compromised.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can use phishing schemes, social engineering tactics, or exploit credential leaks from other breaches to gain access to an account.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and potentially damaging modifications or deletions of user data and application settings.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully phishes an AWS Cognito user's credentials through a convincing email. Without MFA in place, the attacker uses the compromised credentials to log in and access the account, leading to unauthorized data access and potential exploitation of the user's information.

threat.name: Insufficient session management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Poor session management can lead to session hijacking or replay attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit poorly managed sessions, particularly if session identifiers are predictable, not rotated frequently, or not securely stored.
Impacts
Successful exploitation can result in unauthorized access to user accounts, data breaches, and potential financial loss, damaging the company’s reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker captures a user's session token through a man-in-the-middle attack or by accessing logs where tokens are stored improperly. The attacker then uses the token to impersonate the user and gain unauthorized access to sensitive resources.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Consider client-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend that you plan your encryption strategy before implementing your table in DynamoDB. If you store sensitive or confidential data in DynamoDB, consider including client-side encryption in your plan. This way you can encrypt data as close as possible to its origin, and ensure its protection throughout its lifecycle. Encrypting your sensitive data in transit and at rest helps ensure that your plaintext data isn’t available to any third party.

The AWS Database Encryption SDK for DynamoDB is a software library that helps you protect your table data before you send it to DynamoDB. It encrypts, signs, verifies, and decrypts your DynamoDB table items. You control which attributes are encrypted and signed.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Monitor DynamoDB operations using CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
CloudTrail can monitor both control plane events and data plane events. Control plane operations let you create and manage DynamoDB tables. They also let you work with indexes, streams, and other objects that are dependent on tables. Data plane operations let you perform create, read, update, and delete (also called CRUD) actions on data in a table. Some data plane operations also let you read data from a secondary index. To enable logging of data plane events in CloudTrail, you'll need to enable logging of data plane API activity in CloudTrail. See Logging data events for trails for more information.

When activity occurs in DynamoDB, that activity is recorded in a CloudTrail event along with other AWS service events in the event history. For more information, see Logging DynamoDB Operations by Using AWS CloudTrail. You can view, search, and download recent events in your AWS account. For more information, see Viewing Events with CloudTrail Event History in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

For an ongoing record of events in your AWS account, including events for DynamoDB, create a trail. A trail enables CloudTrail to deliver log files to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket. By default, when you create a trail on the console, the trail applies to all AWS Regions. The trail logs events from all Regions in the AWS partition and delivers the log files to the S3 bucket that you specify. Additionally, you can configure other AWS services to further analyze and act upon the event data collected in CloudTrail logs.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Config to monitor configuration changes and ensure compliance with security policies
countermeasure.desc:
Using AWS Config, you can continuously monitor and record configuration changes of your AWS resources. You can also use AWS Config to inventory your AWS resources. When a change from a previous state is detected, an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification can be delivered for you to review and take action. Follow the guidance in Setting Up AWS Config with the Console, ensuring that DynamoDB resource types are included.

You can configure AWS Config to stream configuration changes and notifications to an Amazon SNS topic. For example, when a resource is updated, you can get a notification sent to your email, so that you can view the changes. You can also be notified when AWS Config evaluates your custom or managed rules against your resources.

For an example, see Notifications that AWS Config Sends to an Amazon SNS topic in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB's encryption at rest to secure data stored in tables, backups, and streams
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB encrypts at rest all user data stored in tables, indexes, streams, and backups using encryption keys stored in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). This provides an additional layer of data protection by securing your data from unauthorized access to the underlying storage .

You can specify whether DynamoDB should use an AWS owned key (default encryption type), an AWS managed key, or a customer managed key to encrypt user data. For more information, see Amazon DynamoDB Encryption at Rest.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB Streams to monitor data plane operations
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB is integrated with AWS Lambda so that you can create triggers—pieces of code that automatically respond to events in DynamoDB Streams. With triggers, you can build applications that react to data modifications in DynamoDB tables.

If you enable DynamoDB Streams on a table, you can associate the stream Amazon Resource Name (ARN) with a Lambda function that you write. Immediately after an item in the table is modified, a new record appears in the table's stream. AWS Lambda polls the stream and invokes your Lambda function synchronously when it detects new stream records. The Lambda function can perform any actions that you specify, such as sending a notification or initiating a workflow.

For an example, see Tutorial: Using AWS Lambda with Amazon DynamoDB Streams. This example receives a DynamoDB event input, processes the messages that it contains, and writes some of the incoming event data to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy
RS.AN-1: Notifications from detection systems are investigated
RS.CO-2: Incidents are reported consistent with established criteria

countermeasure.name: Use IAM policy conditions for fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
When you grant permissions in DynamoDB, you can specify conditions that determine how a permissions policy takes effect. Implementing least privilege is key in reducing security risk and the impact that can result from errors or malicious intent.

You can specify conditions when granting permissions using an IAM policy. For example, you can do the following:

  • Grant permissions to allow users read-only access to certain items and attributes in a table or a secondary index.
  • Grant permissions to allow users write-only access to certain attributes in a table, based upon the identity of that user.

For more information, see Using IAM Policy Conditions for Fine-Grained Access Control.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improperly configured IAM policies can lead to unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improperly configured IAM (Identity and Access Management) policies in AWS can result in unauthorized access to DynamoDB tables. These policies govern who can access what resources and with what permissions. Misconfigurations can accidentally grant excessive privileges, allowing unauthorized users to read, write, or delete data, thereby compromising the security of the DynamoDB service.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include internal users such as employees or administrators who might misconfigure policies either accidentally or intentionally. External attackers can exploit stolen AWS credentials or use social engineering techniques to gain access. Automation tools with misconfigured permissions can also inadvertently expose sensitive data.

Impacts

The impacts of this threat include data breaches where sensitive information is exposed, data integrity issues from unauthorized modifications, service disruptions due to unauthorized configuration changes, and potential non-compliance with regulatory requirements, leading to legal and financial repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator accidentally grants excessive permissions to a DynamoDB table, allowing unauthorized internal applications to modify data. A phishing attack leads to compromised AWS credentials, which are then used to exploit an overly permissive policy, resulting in a data breach. A malicious insider with policy management privileges misconfigures policies to gain access to sensitive data, leaking it to external parties. An automation script with broad IAM permissions inadvertently changes access controls, exposing data to unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Without proper monitoring, security incidents can go undetected, leading to prolonged exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Without proper monitoring, security incidents involving AWS DynamoDB can go undetected, allowing malicious activities to persist and causing prolonged exposure to threats. Continuous monitoring is essential for detecting unauthorized access, suspicious activities, and potential security breaches in real-time. Lack of monitoring can result in delayed response to security incidents, increasing the risk of data compromise and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated threats such as malware. Attack vectors can involve exploiting vulnerabilities, using stolen credentials, and performing unauthorized data access or modifications. Absence of monitoring tools and alerting mechanisms makes it easier for these threats to operate undetected over extended periods.

Impacts

Undetected security incidents can lead to severe impacts, including prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive data, extensive data breaches, significant financial losses, and reputational damage. Additionally, prolonged exposure increases the complexity and cost of incident response and recovery, while also potentially resulting in regulatory non-compliance and legal penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

An external attacker exploits a vulnerability to gain access to DynamoDB and exfiltrates sensitive data over several months without detection due to lack of monitoring. A malicious insider continuously accesses and manipulates confidential information in DynamoDB, undetected due to insufficient logging and alerting. Malware infects an application accessing DynamoDB, gradually exfiltrating data without triggering any alerts because of inadequate monitoring. Anomalous access patterns indicating a security breach go unnoticed due to the absence of real-time monitoring and analysis tools.

threat.name: Sensitive data stored in DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in AWS DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access. This can occur due to misconfigurations, inadequate access controls, lack of encryption, or insufficient monitoring. Ensuring that sensitive information such as personal, financial, or proprietary data is protected is critical to maintaining data confidentiality and integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders with sufficient access privileges, external attackers exploiting misconfigured permissions or vulnerabilities, and automated scripts or applications with excessive access rights. Attack vectors can include exploiting weak or default configurations, leveraging compromised credentials, or taking advantage of unencrypted data storage.

Impacts

The exposure of sensitive data can lead to significant consequences such as identity theft, financial loss, damage to reputation, and legal penalties for non-compliance with data protection regulations. Organizations may face operational disruptions, loss of customer trust, and competitive disadvantages if proprietary information is leaked.

Example Attack Scenarios

An insider with administrative privileges accesses and exfiltrates sensitive customer data stored in DynamoDB for personal gain. An external attacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to gain unauthorized access to financial records stored in DynamoDB. A developer accidentally deploys an application with excessive permissions, allowing it to read and expose sensitive data. Lack of encryption at rest results in an attacker accessing unprotected sensitive information directly from the storage medium.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Data transmitted over the network can be intercepted by malicious actors
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data transmitted over a network can be intercepted by malicious actors using various techniques such as man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, or session hijacking. In the context of AWS DynamoDB, data in transit between clients and the database service may be vulnerable if not adequately protected. Intercepted data can lead to exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized access, and manipulation of data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include cybercriminals, hackers, or state-sponsored actors who intercept data using MitM attacks, deploying tools to capture network traffic, or exploiting vulnerabilities in network security protocols. These attackers may gain access through compromised network infrastructure, unsecured Wi-Fi networks, or by exploiting weak encryption standards.

Impacts

The interception of data in transit can result in data breaches, exposing sensitive information such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property. It can also lead to unauthorized data manipulation, where the integrity and authenticity of the data are compromised. Additionally, it may cause loss of trust, reputational damage, and potential legal consequences for failing to protect customer data.

Example Attack Scenarios

A hacker sets up a MitM attack on an unsecured Wi-Fi network, intercepting data transmitted between a client application and the DynamoDB service, capturing sensitive information like authentication tokens and customer data. An attacker uses packet sniffing tools on a compromised network to monitor and extract data being transferred in plaintext due to lack of encryption. A cybercriminal exploits a vulnerability in a network protocol to hijack an active session between a user and the DynamoDB service, gaining unauthorized access to modify and steal data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply IAM policies to restrict access to configure and invoke EventBridge targets
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS EventBridge targets, apply IAM policies that restrict which users and roles have permissions to configure and invoke targets. These policies ensure that only authorized entities can trigger actions on the EventBridge targets, preventing unauthorized operations and maintaining the integrity of the event-driven workflow.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the specific actions (e.g., PutRule, PutTargets, InvokeFunction) that need to be restricted and identify the users and roles that require these permissions.
  2. Create IAM Policies: Develop IAM policies that explicitly define which users and roles are allowed to configure and invoke EventBridge targets. Use least privilege principles to grant only the necessary permissions required for their roles.
  3. Attach Policies to Users and Roles: Attach the IAM policies to the appropriate users, groups, or roles in AWS IAM to enforce the defined access restrictions.
  4. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review IAM policies to ensure they are up-to-date with current organizational requirements and remove any unnecessary permissions.
  5. Monitor Access and Usage: Use AWS CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs to monitor who is configuring and invoking EventBridge targets. Set up alerts for any unauthorized access attempts or actions.

reference.name: Using identity-based policies (IAM policies) for Amazon EventBridge

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable detailed logging for all event activities in AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive visibility and security monitoring in AWS EventBridge, enable detailed logging for all event activities. Use Amazon CloudWatch Logs and AWS CloudTrail to capture and monitor event-related actions, including event publishing, rule evaluation, and target invocation. Detailed logging helps detect unauthorized access, misconfigurations, and anomalies, allowing timely incident response and improving overall security posture.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable CloudTrail for EventBridge: Ensure AWS CloudTrail is enabled for your AWS account to log all EventBridge API calls. Configure CloudTrail to log both management events and data events for comprehensive coverage.
  2. Set Up CloudWatch Logs: Create log groups and set up CloudWatch Logs to capture and store logs generated by EventBridge activities. Ensure logs are retained for an appropriate period based on your organization's retention policy.
  3. Monitor Logs and Set Alerts: Use CloudWatch metrics and alarms to monitor EventBridge activity logs for any unauthorized or suspicious actions. Configure alerts to notify security teams of any anomalies or potential security incidents.
  4. Regularly Review Logs: Schedule regular reviews of CloudWatch Logs and CloudTrail logs to identify trends, detect potential threats, and ensure compliance with security policies.
  5. Audit Log Configurations: Periodically audit logging configurations to ensure that all EventBridge activities are being logged correctly and that logging mechanisms are operating as intended.

reference.name: Logging Amazon EventBridge API calls using AWS CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in event payloads before sending to AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To protect sensitive data transmitted through AWS EventBridge, ensure that all sensitive information included in event payloads is encrypted before being sent. Use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for encrypting data to safeguard against unauthorized access and potential data breaches. Encrypting sensitive data ensures its confidentiality and integrity, even if it is intercepted or accessed by unauthorized parties.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Sensitive Data: Determine which data fields in event payloads contain sensitive information that requires encryption, such as personally identifiable information (PII) or financial details.
  2. Use AWS KMS for Encryption: Utilize AWS KMS to encrypt sensitive data within the payloads. Integrate AWS KMS encryption into your application's event generation process to automatically encrypt sensitive data before sending it to EventBridge.
  3. Encrypt Data in Transit: Ensure that encrypted payloads are transmitted over secure channels, such as HTTPS, to add another layer of protection during data transit.
  4. Regularly Review Encryption Policies: Periodically review and update encryption practices and KMS key policies to align with organizational security standards and compliance requirements.
  5. Audit Encrypted Payloads: Regularly audit event payloads to verify that sensitive data is properly encrypted and that no plaintext sensitive information is sent through EventBridge.

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

countermeasure.name: Regularly review and validate event rule configurations in AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain secure and efficient event routing in AWS EventBridge, regularly review and validate the configuration of event rules. Ensure that each rule routes events only to authorized targets and that the configurations are not overly permissive. This practice adheres to the principle of least privilege, minimizing the risk of unauthorized actions or data exposure.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Schedule Regular Rule Reviews: Establish a routine schedule for reviewing all EventBridge event rules to ensure they are properly configured and align with security policies.
  2. Validate Target Authorizations: Check that each event rule routes events only to authorized targets, and ensure that no unauthorized targets are included.
  3. Minimize Rule Permissions: Review rule conditions and filters to ensure they are specific and not overly broad or permissive. Adjust configurations to follow the principle of least privilege.
  4. Document and Track Changes: Maintain a log of all rule reviews and any changes made to event rule configurations for auditing purposes.
  5. Automate Validation Checks: Where possible, automate the validation of event rule configurations using AWS Config or custom scripts to identify any non-compliant or overly permissive rules.

reference.name: Creating a rule that runs on a schedule in Amazon EventBridge

PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
